page.title: 06Hafod in the 20th century
page.content: By the beginning of the 20th century, many of the industries had closed down because the supplies of iron ore from Devon and Cornwall were declining. {Large numbers of sites became derelict {and buildings fell down. At this time {Hafod was called Vivianton or {Vivians town after the copper works {owners, although Hafod is a Welsh name {meaning 'summer place'.}Most of the streets in Hafod are named after men who built factories. Vernon Street is named after George Vernon of Briton Ferry, Earl Street after William Villiers and Odo Street after Odo Richard. The Vivians built the school and St.Johns church. Hafod exists today solely as a result of the copper industry.
